children.text: Pinky, a chaffeur and correspondence school detective, played by Webb King. Pinky has been hired by Manuel Romero to track down Helen Childers, so that Romero can trick her into signing away her land. Pinky's role provides some comic relief to the story, as seen here in his "disguise."

children.text: Phillip Jones, played by Clarence Brooks. Phillip is a young lawyer who admires Juanita Cooper, the adopted daughter of Frank and Geraldine Cooper. Brooks was one of the original members of the Lincoln Motion Picture Company and featured in a number of their films.

children.text: Lew Meeham as Manuel Romero, "unscrupulous stockbroker" and Grace Ellenwood as Geraldine Cooper, Juanita's foster mother who resents the girl and is deeply in gambling debt. Geraldine has enlisted Romero to help her recoup her debts, and Romero works to con unsuspecting Freedmen  Black individuals who were formerly enslaved by Native American tribes  out of valuable land in Oklahoma. Romero receives a letter from an offie in Oklahoma about a lease of land. "Manuel Romero, Dear Sir, I was informed at register's office that you would have to properly identify Helen Childers signature. Would advise that you procure six affidavits. And send for at once. Yours truly, James Davis".

annotation.text: By Right of Birth premiered on June 22 and 23, 1921 at the Trinity Auditorium. The auditorium had a capacity of 1,527 seated, but the Lincoln Company had to install a screen and picture player in the space. Hear George P. Johnson describe the exhibition of the film here:

children.text: Lester "Leo" Bates as Frank Cooper, Juanita's adopted father. Frank found Juanita as a baby after her family's crash on the way to California and dotes lovingly on her.

As a result of treaties between the U.S. federal government and Native American tribes in now-Oklahoma, the once-communal land had been divided into individual allotments. When oil and gas was discovered, making those land allotments extremely valuable, white settlers used legal guardianship and other means of abuse to manipulate the land, money, and legal power from their rightful Native American owners, which was enabled by various federal policies. For Freedmen, former enslaved people of the Native American tribes, this was made even more complex by many tribes' refusal to acknowledge federal treaties regarding their citizenship rights.

Beatrice George as Mother Agnes. Mother Agnes is a matronly woman who helps young colored girls in need of a home. She is actually Agnes Childers, who came to California from Oklahoma seeking her long-lost daughter, Helen. By the end of the film, Juanita discovers that she is Helen Childers and that Mother Agnes is actually her birth mother.
